T1NDER the superintendent and instruction of W1LLIA

The Of instruction pursued at this seminary
prises all the useful and of the Ornamental branches
of female education. The daily exercises are, Orthogrs
ply, Reading, Writing, Arithmetic English Grammar
Rhetoric Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with reference to the best maps and charts Con-
sructon of maps; Use of the Gobesl Natural History
Natural Philosophy including Astronomy and Chemistry;
Elements Of Moral Science.


Weekly Ererci.es.-Bibicsl Recltions Evidences Of
Christianity; Letter Writing and other species Of Com
position; Recapituations.


Terms.-Board and tuition in any Of the foregoing
branches $3.50 per quarter If paid in ADVANCE $50
Music including the of piano. S12 French by
Of the best masters Sc quarter Moderate extra char
ges for Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline Of the school mild parental ard chris
tan Particular attention paid only the
of the young ladies' but to their moral and religious in
strucuon They regularly conducted to such places
of worship and Sunday Schools their parents and guar


dams approve Exercise and recreston being essential
to the preservation of health and of mental energy
by the intervals Of time not devoted to study lhe ins
tuition, in all it's departments is conducted in manner
which, it is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation os
/ its patrons.

From the recent transactions 10 Congress, and
elsewhere, among the opposition, it appears that
they Intend to make the Presidential Question turn
on the powers Of the General Government, with
respect to Internal improvement, and the encour-
sgement Of Domestic Manufactures, and the Amer.
ican or Home System.


The opposition, it appears, are forming COM
binations," not only to oppose the present Admin
istraiion right or wrong, and elect Gen. Jackson
president, it possible. but to oppose Internal I'm
provement; oppose Domestic Manufactures and
the American System, and, in fact, while their
avowed object is to elect General Jackson president.
their real object Isl or its tendency will be, to
retard the strides Of this nouiishing Republic. to
wehlth and prospefity--to make us dependent
instead Of an independent nation. Al proof Of
these facts, look at the late votes on these great
national questions in Congsess:- with few excep-
lions the opposition have voted agsint them.
But look nearer home. Our Representative.
who heretofore has upheld and supported Domes-
tic Manufactures, and who was supported, and elect
ed at the last election, principally on the ground Of
his being the tried and faithful friend OF our Man
ufactures, has now deserted his post, and in his
votes on the " Woolen 3ill'' has drawn aside the
mask, and We now see him, as he really 10, opposed
to the american System. He has turned traitor to
his best friends, who fervcnty supported his last
election. We see that Mr.. Hsrker. who always
ollOWd III MS wake, Hdb Cnankcu 8iuSb AHu
now opposing Domestic Manufacturer which he
formerly advocated What does oil this mean ?
Are the public blind, not 10 these Inconsistencies
They do, and will them, and will act as It be
comes lreemen and Americans.


Will not these facts have some influence on the
people of Delaware. Pennsylvania, New York, and
elsewherei Will the people of Pennsylvania, who
are so deeply interested in manufactures, support
men who disregard her interests? Will she sup
port Presidential candidate whose line Of policy
will be opposed to her best nterestsf Tho inde-
pendent freemen Of ihs, great State can answer the
question Although they esteem Gen. Jackson,
for his military services, will they sacrifice their
best interests 10 the mani Il is not probable. -
When they called on TO choose electors for
President. they will doubt inquire, whether
Gen. Jackson, who they wish we'll, and esteem as
great man. will support the .anerican System Il
they satisfied he will not, they most sssuredly
will not support him. They cannot. And further
can the friends OF American Manufactures in Del
/ aware, who supported Mr.. Mclane on ths ground
Of his devotion to the manufacturing interest," follow
him, when he has deserted his former principles
We no doubt shall see to the contrary. II ne 10 in
consistent, his talents and dazzling influence, will
not make them 80. II they are consistent with
themselves they surely will be opposed to the course
he has lately pursued.


The Toice Of Truth.

Washington. March S.


The proceedings Of the last Session oi the Con-
press, which closed it's term Saturday, and espe.
eally those of the Senate will receive the serious
confederation Of the people Of the United States.
Iis our purpose hereafter to notice them more par
ticusry. II need not be disguised that towards the
close Of the past Session, we presume by soms OF
those combinations" of which Or. FLOYD. IN his
late address at Richmond made precious comics.
sion, the opposition obtained small majority in the
Senate. We will select only few prominent in
stances TO show how this majority was disposed 10
use the ephemer power SO obtained.


i The wool bill, (this measure so important to
the great interests Of country was, in effect re-
iected by the casting vote Of Mr.. CALHOUN, the
Vice President.


Q. A committee appointed by the majority OF the
Senate, made long report on the subject OF the
Georgia controversy, Of which three thousand CO.
pics we're ordered to be printed for distribution a.
mong the people of the United States. counenan-
cling and encouraging the Governor Of Georgia.

8. The bill for converting portion ofthe six per
cent. debt, into debt bearing an interest OF fve
per cent which passed the House of Representa-
tives was lost in the Senate. BY the failure to pass
bill last year, in consequence Of The now acknowl
edged error Of Mr.. LOUIS McLANE, the country
lost about ninety thousand dollars. BY the failure
of the Senate to pass this bill it loses like sum.


q. The Colonial bill was lost by the refusal Of the
Senate to agree to an amendment Of the House Of
Representatives, without which the measure would
have humilined this country. And now Great Brit
ain is left in possession of the monopoly OF the nav
igation concerned 10 the intercourse, unless the
President feels himself authorized to close ports
under the act OF March, 1925.


Whatever regret will be felt at the course pursu-
ed by the Senate in the above instances, the people
will derive much satisfaction from knowing that that
Of their immediate Representatives was directly the
reverse Of il.


We must add, as one Of the remarkable insidenis
Of the last Session Of the Senate, that Duff Green
the editor OF paper, notorious for the scurrty
OF its columns and its utter disregard OF all decency
and truth received the votes Of twenty-threc SENA
TORS Of the United States to be the printer Of the
Senate. Nat. Journal

ed by Mr. MLanes error alluded above. An exposi.
ton Of this subject might serve good purpose.]

Captain Doane, Of the revenue cutter Marion,
arrived at Charleston Sunday the 25th ult, in
three days from Key West, states that on the 18th
ult. Commodore Porter put to sea with his whole
squadron, consisting Of


! The Frigate Libertad, Of 40 guns, 1st Lieut..
David II. Porter, captain Brig Victoria, of 90
guns, Lieut.. Jose Maria Machin, captain Brig
Bravo, of Is guns, 1st Lieut.. William A. Wise,
| captain and the Schooner Herman, of guns,
| 1st Lieut.. Juan Nanez captain.


| The squadron had to beat out against strong
wind and tide to cross the reef and reach the
enemy, and after succeeding in coming within five
miles of him, he set all sail and was soon out Of
| sight. Night coming on, and the passage OF the
rect being difficult in the dark. the squadron re-
turned to its former anchorage


The Captain states that Commodore Porter hat
taken several prizes; and has brought correspon
tdence between the Commodore and the civil ant


naval authorities Of Cuba, from which it appears
that on the Cd of January, he set at liberty thu


master, mate, and % seamen, being the crew o
the Spanish merchant brig the Hercules, togethe
with five eccesiastics who were passengers ant
| that he still detained the master and crew of
Spanish slave trader, the Manteneza, which he Of


fered to liberate on receiving security that they


should not again be employed in the same trade.

FOR THE WArcHMAH.

THE PRESIDENTIAL QUESTION
full articles.article:
From the recent transactions 10 Congress, and
elsewhere, among the opposition, it appears that
they Intend to make the Presidential Question turn
on the powers Of the General Government, with
respect to Internal improvement, and the encour-
sgement Of Domestic Manufactures, and the Amer.
ican or Home System.


The opposition, it appears, are forming COM
binations," not only to oppose the present Admin
istraiion right or wrong, and elect Gen. Jackson
president, it possible. but to oppose Internal I'm
provement; oppose Domestic Manufactures and
the American System, and, in fact, while their
avowed object is to elect General Jackson president.
their real object Isl or its tendency will be, to
retard the strides Of this nouiishing Republic. to
wehlth and prospefity--to make us dependent
instead Of an independent nation. Al proof Of
these facts, look at the late votes on these great
national questions in Congsess:- with few excep-
lions the opposition have voted agsint them.
But look nearer home. Our Representative.
who heretofore has upheld and supported Domes-
tic Manufactures, and who was supported, and elect
ed at the last election, principally on the ground Of
his being the tried and faithful friend OF our Man
ufactures, has now deserted his post, and in his
votes on the " Woolen 3ill'' has drawn aside the
mask, and We now see him, as he really 10, opposed
to the american System. He has turned traitor to
his best friends, who fervcnty supported his last
election. We see that Mr.. Hsrker. who always
ollOWd III MS wake, Hdb Cnankcu 8iuSb AHu
now opposing Domestic Manufacturer which he
formerly advocated What does oil this mean ?
Are the public blind, not 10 these Inconsistencies
They do, and will them, and will act as It be
comes lreemen and Americans.


Will not these facts have some influence on the
people of Delaware. Pennsylvania, New York, and
elsewherei Will the people of Pennsylvania, who
are so deeply interested in manufactures, support
men who disregard her interests? Will she sup
port Presidential candidate whose line Of policy
will be opposed to her best nterestsf Tho inde-
pendent freemen Of ihs, great State can answer the
question Although they esteem Gen. Jackson,
for his military services, will they sacrifice their
best interests 10 the mani Il is not probable. -
When they called on TO choose electors for
President. they will doubt inquire, whether
Gen. Jackson, who they wish we'll, and esteem as
great man. will support the .anerican System Il
they satisfied he will not, they most sssuredly
will not support him. They cannot. And further
can the friends OF American Manufactures in Del
/ aware, who supported Mr.. Mclane on ths ground
Of his devotion to the manufacturing interest," follow
him, when he has deserted his former principles
We no doubt shall see to the contrary. II ne 10 in
consistent, his talents and dazzling influence, will
not make them 80. II they are consistent with
themselves they surely will be opposed to the course
he has lately pursued.


The Toice Of Truth.

Messrs. EplToas-The fiends OF the present
administrator need not, think, be under any ap.
prshension of injury from the pen Of that model Of
consistency. Corporal Samuel Harker. If be true,
and have no doubt it is, tha. in 1922 he expressed
his opinion Of General Jackson as quoted in several
of your late papers, no need be surprised to see,
IN few years, all the abuse ct present heaped on
lhe administration, turned into the most sycophan-
ic favning which the English language is capsble
afexpressing.


His former abuse Of YaGxson has been such as the
annals Of Billingsgate caunot surpass; now behold
aow changed! Ths little csmelion assumcs another
colour the Corporal has rallied to the Jackson
Standard, aud will be consistent and dissin-

full articles.article:
COMMUNICATES
DIED-Near Niddletown, Del, on the evening Of the
oath ult, after illness of nearly week, in the
26th year Of her age, Mrs. MARY MERRITT, cohsor'
of Thos S. Merritt, and eldest daughter Of Benjamin
Noxon, dec.


"The deep, damp vault may triumph o'er its guest;
But dust to dust its noblest song shall be;
The happy SOUL in cimes of glory bles


Shall be snshrined in Immortality"

We suspect that one thing which has tended to


nroyoke our irritable friend, nelghbor iiarker AMI


nut him into such an uncommon Ill humor, is, the
fact, that in the long discussion OF Mr.: Saunders
4 Yps
HE name was not introduced, his pltiable case was
not mentioned, and none mourned for him. Con
,acr;nu his devotion to MIR. MLane. we think he
had right to expect that that gentleman would
have appeared as his champion, and we 40 not
wonder that his disappointment has chaied hlm.
There is passage in Shakespeare, which, by an


alteration Of two words, gives correct description
of the editorial character of hottempered little
man down town, who has lately received com
mission from Governor, who, we suppose, has
acted on the old proverb, that one good turn de-
serves another" The passage, altered, reads
thus.
Sammy Harker aspeaks an Infinite deal OF
4 nothing, more than any man IN all" WiiminStoh
his reasons are as two grains OF wheat hid IN two
bnsbels If chatf: YOU shall seek all day ere you
find them and when you have them, they are not
worth the Search


we nerceiye by the Delaware Gazette OF Tues
dsy last. that Mr.. Harker is very much enraged
at us on account Of our exposition oil ms ncpnss-
tency as shown in his former opinion OF Gen Jack
son and his present support OF "Old HICKORY,
In the overflowings of his malice towards U.S. Mr.
Harker has broken through all the bounds OF de
cency and truth, and we cannot degrade ourselves
by STOPPING to combat with him with the weapons
which he uses.
We have the paper of which we speak," ant
we have shown it to number OF sentiemeh' aho
some Of them Mr. Harker's intimate acqualntances
for whose opinion he entertains high regard
and all of them agree that we have not mlsrepre
sented Mr.. Harker's opinion of Gen. jackson, a.
EXPRESSED by him in his Gazette of Nov |, 1892
In the Gazette Of that date Mr.. ila,ker does
after expressly mentioning that Mcssrs. Clay
Clinton, Jackson, Adams, Calhoun, and Crawford
were candidates for the Presidency, make use Q
the following language:


nof ALL the gentlemen named, Gen. Jackson appear
to us to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE That he
man Of energy, will doubt, but we thinS INA
in chief magistrate of the United States, too much er
eryyn extremely dangerous; AND ve have seen in II
GENERAL .ueh q DISREGARD FOR THE INsTITt
TlONS Of the csuntyy such DISPOSITION 20 pdt
himself ABOVE ia La,ss AND sueh an INCLINATION
TRAMPLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS. whe
they stood in competition with HIS OWN INTEREST
FEELINGS, a. should render the citizens of the Unite


States vry cautious about placing him in the first ofc
within their gift"


Now we insist upon it, that unless Mr.. Harker'
ALL can be construed to mean ONLY pAR
Of the aforementioned six candidates tor the Of
fee Of President, we have not been guilty OF mis-
representing his language. But to put this matte
at rest we challenge Mr.. Harker to republish tn
article Of Nov l, 1922, which has given rise to IN
dispute in question. We shall wait to see wheti
er he will comply with this reasonable request,
I he does not we shall be compiled to give il plac
in the columns Of the Watchman.


---<o oecccn -

full articles.headline: Washington, March S.
full articles.article:
Washington. March S.


The proceedings Of the last Session oi the Con-
press, which closed it's term Saturday, and espe.
eally those of the Senate will receive the serious
confederation Of the people Of the United States.
Iis our purpose hereafter to notice them more par
ticusry. II need not be disguised that towards the
close Of the past Session, we presume by soms OF
those combinations" of which Or. FLOYD. IN his
late address at Richmond made precious comics.
sion, the opposition obtained small majority in the
Senate. We will select only few prominent in
stances TO show how this majority was disposed 10
use the ephemer power SO obtained.


i The wool bill, (this measure so important to
the great interests Of country was, in effect re-
iected by the casting vote Of Mr.. CALHOUN, the
Vice President.


Q. A committee appointed by the majority OF the
Senate, made long report on the subject OF the
Georgia controversy, Of which three thousand CO.
pics we're ordered to be printed for distribution a.
mong the people of the United States. counenan-
cling and encouraging the Governor Of Georgia.

believe it may be relied upon sit came from respect
able Merchants MENTOR.

8. The bill for converting portion ofthe six per
cent. debt, into debt bearing an interest OF fve
per cent which passed the House of Representa-
tives was lost in the Senate. BY the failure to pass
bill last year, in consequence Of The now acknowl
edged error Of Mr.. LOUIS McLANE, the country
lost about ninety thousand dollars. BY the failure
of the Senate to pass this bill it loses like sum.


q. The Colonial bill was lost by the refusal Of the
Senate to agree to an amendment Of the House Of
Representatives, without which the measure would
have humilined this country. And now Great Brit
ain is left in possession of the monopoly OF the nav
igation concerned 10 the intercourse, unless the
President feels himself authorized to close ports
under the act OF March, 1925.


Whatever regret will be felt at the course pursu-
ed by the Senate in the above instances, the people
will derive much satisfaction from knowing that that
Of their immediate Representatives was directly the
reverse Of il.


We must add, as one Of the remarkable insidenis
Of the last Session Of the Senate, that Duff Green
the editor OF paper, notorious for the scurrty
OF its columns and its utter disregard OF all decency
and truth received the votes Of twenty-threc SENA
TORS Of the United States to be the printer Of the
Senate. Nat. Journal


[Noe-The Editor Of the Journal would confer favor
the public by stating the particulars of the oss occasion
ed by Mr. MLanes error alluded above. An exposi.
ton Of this subject might serve good purpose.]
sic


Captain Doane, Of the revenue cutter Marion,
arrived at Charleston Sunday the 25th ult, in
three days from Key West, states that on the 18th
ult. Commodore Porter put to sea with his whole
squadron, consisting Of


! The Frigate Libertad, Of 40 guns, 1st Lieut..
David II. Porter, captain Brig Victoria, of 90
guns, Lieut.. Jose Maria Machin, captain Brig
Bravo, of Is guns, 1st Lieut.. William A. Wise,
| captain and the Schooner Herman, of guns,
| 1st Lieut.. Juan Nanez captain.


| The squadron had to beat out against strong
wind and tide to cross the reef and reach the
enemy, and after succeeding in coming within five
miles of him, he set all sail and was soon out Of
| sight. Night coming on, and the passage OF the
rect being difficult in the dark. the squadron re-
turned to its former anchorage


The Captain states that Commodore Porter hat
taken several prizes; and has brought correspon
tdence between the Commodore and the civil ant


naval authorities Of Cuba, from which it appears
that on the Cd of January, he set at liberty thu


master, mate, and % seamen, being the crew o
the Spanish merchant brig the Hercules, togethe
with five eccesiastics who were passengers ant
| that he still detained the master and crew of
Spanish slave trader, the Manteneza, which he Of


fered to liberate on receiving security that they


should not again be employed in the same trade.

was caused it is said, by serious disappointment.
